==Response==
+
==Domestic responses==
â
===Domestic===
+
===Executive===
â
====Executive====
 
Prior to the outbreak of the larger scale protests and the first domestic crackdown, King [[Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa]]'s announcement of giving {{currency|1000|BHD}} to each family.<ref name="AFP_3kdollars" /><ref name="aljazbahrain" /> This was interpreted by ''Al Jazeera'' as a favour to all Bahraini citzens.<ref name="aljazbahrain" /> The King also offered to increase social spending and to release minors jailed after the August 2010 protests.<ref name="aljazbahrain">{{cite news|author = [[Staff writer]]|url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121251854857192.html |title = Bahrain Doles Out Money to Families|publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=12 February 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> On 15 February, on television King Hamad offered condolences for the deaths of two protesters, said that a parliamentary committee to investigate the deaths would be created, and stated that peaceful protests are legal.<ref name="aljaz_protestdeaths" /> The following day the president of the [[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] [[Nabeel Rajab]] said that the King's response was not enough to satisfy protesters' demands.<ref name="alj_16Feb">{{cite news | author = [[Staff writer]] | title = Bahrain Protesters Hold Ground â Anti-Government Protests Continue in Tiny Kingdom, Despite Apology by King for the Deaths of Two Demonstrators | date=16 February 2011 | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121635518925202.html | accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wY7a5QCD | archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> After the government crackdown with the support of Saudi Arabia, the king said that "An external plot has been fomented for 20 to 30 years until the ground was ripe for subversive designs...I here announce the failure of the fomented plot."<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/21/bahrain-protests-king-idUSLDE72K01O20110321 "Bahrain King Says Forces Have Foiled Foreign Plot"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> He also thanked the GCC states for their intervention.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201132174237751604.html Bahrain king speaks of 'foiled foreign plot' â Middle East]. [[Al Jazeera English]]. 21 March 2011. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref>
Prior to the outbreak of the larger scale protests and the first domestic crackdown, King [[Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa]]'s announcement of giving {{currency|1000|BHD}} to each family.<ref name="AFP_3kdollars" /><ref name="aljazbahrain" /> This was interpreted by ''Al Jazeera'' as a favour to all Bahraini citzens.<ref name="aljazbahrain" /> The King also offered to increase social spending and to release minors jailed after the August 2010 protests.<ref name="aljazbahrain">{{cite news|author = [[Staff writer]]|url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121251854857192.html |title = Bahrain Doles Out Money to Families|publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] |date=12 February 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> On 15 February, on television King Hamad offered condolences for the deaths of two protesters, said that a parliamentary committee to investigate the deaths would be created, and stated that peaceful protests are legal.<ref name="aljaz_protestdeaths" /> The following day the president of the [[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] [[Nabeel Rajab]] said that the King's response was not enough to satisfy protesters' demands.<ref name="alj_16Feb">{{cite news | author = [[Staff writer]] | title = Bahrain Protesters Hold Ground â Anti-Government Protests Continue in Tiny Kingdom, Despite Apology by King for the Deaths of Two Demonstrators | date=16 February 2011 | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121635518925202.html | accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wY7a5QCD | archivedate=16 February 2011 |deadurl=no }}</ref> After the government crackdown with the support of Saudi Arabia, the king said that "An external plot has been fomented for 20 to 30 years until the ground was ripe for subversive designs...I here announce the failure of the fomented plot."<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/21/bahrain-protests-king-idUSLDE72K01O20110321 "Bahrain King Says Forces Have Foiled Foreign Plot"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref> He also thanked the GCC states for their intervention.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201132174237751604.html Bahrain king speaks of 'foiled foreign plot' â Middle East]. [[Al Jazeera English]]. 21 March 2011. Retrieved 9 April 2011.</ref>
He called for "dialogue" and a direction that the King's son, Crown Prince [[Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa]], work on a resolution to the conflict.<ref name="bloombergresponse"/> On 13 March, in a televised statement, Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa renewed his call for national dialogue, promising talks would address key demands such as bolstering the power of parliament and that any deal could be put to a referendum. He said talks would also cover electoral and governmental reforms, as well as looking into claims of corruption and sectarianism.<ref name="AJBahr13Mar"/>
He called for "dialogue" and a direction that the King's son, Crown Prince [[Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa]], work on a resolution to the conflict.<ref name="bloombergresponse"/> On 13 March, in a televised statement, Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa renewed his call for national dialogue, promising talks would address key demands such as bolstering the power of parliament and that any deal could be put to a referendum. He said talks would also cover electoral and governmental reforms, as well as looking into claims of corruption and sectarianism.<ref name="AJBahr13Mar"/>
â
====Legislature====
+
===Legislature===
Abdul Jalil Khalil, an Al Wefaq National Islamic Society member of parliament, described the 17 February pre-dawn police raid on the Pearl Roundabout encampment as "real terrorism", stating that "whoever took the decision to attack the protest was aiming to kill."<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb" /> Its MP Jassim Hussein said that "I don't think the regime is willing to meet most of our demands. But even if it does, I am not sure it will be enough to get the youth off the street. It is personal now." Following demands from young protesters for the end of the ruling regime<ref>{{cite web | author = Sotloff, Steven | url = http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792189&Itemid=347 | title = Bahrain Protesters Took Back Pearl Square. What Next? | publisher = [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] | date=20 February 2011 | accessdate=22 April 2011}}</ref> and in protest against the deaths during demontrations, all eighteen party MPs submitted their official resignations from parliament.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
Abdul Jalil Khalil, an Al Wefaq National Islamic Society member of parliament, described the 17 February pre-dawn police raid on the Pearl Roundabout encampment as "real terrorism", stating that "whoever took the decision to attack the protest was aiming to kill."<ref name="aljaz_bahr17Feb" /> Its MP Jassim Hussein said that "I don't think the regime is willing to meet most of our demands. But even if it does, I am not sure it will be enough to get the youth off the street. It is personal now." Following demands from young protesters for the end of the ruling regime<ref>{{cite web | author = Sotloff, Steven | url = http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792189&Itemid=347 | title = Bahrain Protesters Took Back Pearl Square. What Next? | publisher = [[Foundation for Defense of Democracies]] | date=20 February 2011 | accessdate=22 April 2011}}</ref> and in protest against the deaths during demontrations, all eighteen party MPs submitted their official resignations from parliament.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
Four members of the Shura council, the upper house of parliament, [[Mohamed Hadi al-Halawji]], [[Mohamed Baqir Hasan Radi]], [[Nasser al-Mubarak]] and [[Nada Hafad]] resigned in protests against the crackdown. Hafad quit first accusing the government and [[state media]] of attempting to foment divisions within Bahraini society.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net"/>
Four members of the Shura council, the upper house of parliament, [[Mohamed Hadi al-Halawji]], [[Mohamed Baqir Hasan Radi]], [[Nasser al-Mubarak]] and [[Nada Hafad]] resigned in protests against the crackdown. Hafad quit first accusing the government and [[state media]] of attempting to foment divisions within Bahraini society.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net"/>
â
===International===
+
==International reactions==
â
====[[Supranational]] bodies====
+
===[[Supranational]] bodies===
{{flagicon|GCC}} [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] members agreed to provide Bahrain with an aid plan similar to the [[Marshall Plan]], consisting of US$10 billion aimed at upgrading housing and infrastructure over a period of ten years.<ref name="AJBahr10Mar">{{cite news | title = Sectarian Clashes at Bahrain School â Violence Between Shia and Sunni Parents at School as Gulf Nation Braces Itself for Friday's March on the Royal Court | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011310201330454225.html | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date=10 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5yRqPlfHJ |archivedate=5 May 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref> They also agreed that they would give more preference to GCC-member state nationals while hiring individuals.<ref>{{cite web | author = Toumi, Habib | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/gcc-marshall-style-aid-package-for-bahrain-oman-1.770473 | title = GCC Marshall-Style Aid Package for Bahrain, Oman | work = [[Gulf News]] | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> A statement issued on 10 March from the foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates and the GCC said it supported recent calls for dialogue from Bahrain's crown prince.<ref name="AJBahr10Mar"/>
{{flagicon|GCC}} [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] members agreed to provide Bahrain with an aid plan similar to the [[Marshall Plan]], consisting of US$10 billion aimed at upgrading housing and infrastructure over a period of ten years.<ref name="AJBahr10Mar">{{cite news | title = Sectarian Clashes at Bahrain School â Violence Between Shia and Sunni Parents at School as Gulf Nation Braces Itself for Friday's March on the Royal Court | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011310201330454225.html | publisher = [[Al Jazeera English]] | date=10 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5yRqPlfHJ |archivedate=5 May 2011 |deadurl=no}}</ref> They also agreed that they would give more preference to GCC-member state nationals while hiring individuals.<ref>{{cite web | author = Toumi, Habib | url = http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/gcc-marshall-style-aid-package-for-bahrain-oman-1.770473 | title = GCC Marshall-Style Aid Package for Bahrain, Oman | work = [[Gulf News]] | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=19 April 2011}}</ref> A statement issued on 10 March from the foreign minister of the United Arab Emirates and the GCC said it supported recent calls for dialogue from Bahrain's crown prince.<ref name="AJBahr10Mar"/>
Line 417: Line 417:
{{flagicon|UN}} [[United Nations]] [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Navi Pillay]] said that a takeover by security forces of any medical facilities was a "blatant violation of international law. There are '[also]' reports of arbitrary arrests, killings, beatings of protesters and of medical personnel, and of the takeover of hospitals and medical centres by various security forces. This is shocking and illegal conduct."<ref name="blog17march">[[Staff writer]] (17 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/middle-east/live-blog-bahrain-unrest "Live Blog: Bahrain Unrest"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 16 April 2011.</ref>
{{flagicon|UN}} [[United Nations]] [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Navi Pillay]] said that a takeover by security forces of any medical facilities was a "blatant violation of international law. There are '[also]' reports of arbitrary arrests, killings, beatings of protesters and of medical personnel, and of the takeover of hospitals and medical centres by various security forces. This is shocking and illegal conduct."<ref name="blog17march">[[Staff writer]] (17 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/middle-east/live-blog-bahrain-unrest "Live Blog: Bahrain Unrest"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. Retrieved 16 April 2011.</ref>
â
====States====
+
===States===
{{flag|India}} â After Friday prayers protesters in [[Lucknow]] rallied in condemnation of Saudi Arabia after Syed Kalbe Jawad said: "Saudi forces are killing innocent civilians in Bahrain only for holding anti-government demonstrations. I appeal for holding such protest in other parts of the country. Bahraini demonstrators are being killed by bullets coming from helicopters and also with poisonous gases. The people's uprising is aimed at restoring democracy and it is justifiable. Those sitting at the helm of affairs should read the writing on the wall and pave the way for democracy." He also said that should the Saudi soldiers not be withdrawn protesters would continue to agitate in the capital [[New Delhi]].<ref>[[Staff writer]] (18 March 2011). [http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170616.html "Indians Slam Saudi Presence in Bahrain"]. [[Press TV]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011.</ref>
{{flag|India}} â After Friday prayers protesters in [[Lucknow]] rallied in condemnation of Saudi Arabia after Syed Kalbe Jawad said: "Saudi forces are killing innocent civilians in Bahrain only for holding anti-government demonstrations. I appeal for holding such protest in other parts of the country. Bahraini demonstrators are being killed by bullets coming from helicopters and also with poisonous gases. The people's uprising is aimed at restoring democracy and it is justifiable. Those sitting at the helm of affairs should read the writing on the wall and pave the way for democracy." He also said that should the Saudi soldiers not be withdrawn protesters would continue to agitate in the capital [[New Delhi]].<ref>[[Staff writer]] (18 March 2011). [http://www.presstv.ir/detail/170616.html "Indians Slam Saudi Presence in Bahrain"]. [[Press TV]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011.</ref>
Line 438: Line 438:
{{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]] said he was "deeply concerned" by the violence,<ref name="bloombergresponse">{{cite news | author = Carey, Glen; Alexander, Caroline | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html | title = Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date=18 February 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> while [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] urged restraint.<ref>{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/21/c_13741314.htm | title = Clinton Calls for Restraint in Bahrain | publisher = [[Xinhua News Agency]] | date=20 February 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> [[George Washington University]] Professor [[Hossein Askari (professor)|Hossein Askari]] blamed the "power of the [[Saudi Arabia lobby|Saudi lobby]] in Washington" for the failure of the American government to defend the democracy protesters in Bahrain in 2011.<ref name="Askari">Askari, Hossein; essay (18 March 2011). [http://nationalinterest.org/commentary/marriage-made-hell-5039?page=2 "A Marriage Made in Hell"]. ''[[The National Interest]]''. Retrieved 21 April 2011.</ref> On 30 April, Obama spoke to the Bahraini king by phone and reportedly told him that the U.S. position is that [[Manama]] must make political reforms and respect the "universal rights" of the Bahraini people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/politico44/perm/0411/long_distance_116efb9e-ca50-4ba7-be23-f14cd0105462.html|agency=Politico|date=30 April 2011|accessdate=1 May 2011|title=Obama dials Bahrain, Kazakhstan}}</ref>
{{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]] said he was "deeply concerned" by the violence,<ref name="bloombergresponse">{{cite news | author = Carey, Glen; Alexander, Caroline | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-17/bahrain-security-forces-kill-two-people-overnight-human-rights-groups-say.html | title = Bahrain's King Seeks Talks With Foes Amid Clashes in Region | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date=18 February 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> while [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] urged restraint.<ref>{{cite web | author = [[Staff writer]] | url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/21/c_13741314.htm | title = Clinton Calls for Restraint in Bahrain | publisher = [[Xinhua News Agency]] | date=20 February 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> [[George Washington University]] Professor [[Hossein Askari (professor)|Hossein Askari]] blamed the "power of the [[Saudi Arabia lobby|Saudi lobby]] in Washington" for the failure of the American government to defend the democracy protesters in Bahrain in 2011.<ref name="Askari">Askari, Hossein; essay (18 March 2011). [http://nationalinterest.org/commentary/marriage-made-hell-5039?page=2 "A Marriage Made in Hell"]. ''[[The National Interest]]''. Retrieved 21 April 2011.</ref> On 30 April, Obama spoke to the Bahraini king by phone and reportedly told him that the U.S. position is that [[Manama]] must make political reforms and respect the "universal rights" of the Bahraini people.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/politico44/perm/0411/long_distance_116efb9e-ca50-4ba7-be23-f14cd0105462.html|agency=Politico|date=30 April 2011|accessdate=1 May 2011|title=Obama dials Bahrain, Kazakhstan}}</ref>
â
====[[Non-governmental organization]]s====
+
===[[Non-governmental organization]]s===
[[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] both condemned the use of excessive violence against peaceful demonstrators in Bahrain.<ref>{{dead link|date=April 2011|reason=link appears to be dynamic or index page. what is precise attribution?}} {{cite web | author = | url = http://www.amnesty.org/en/region/bahrain | title = Bahrain | Amnesty International | publisher = [[Amnesty International]] | date=11 February 2011 | accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{dead link|date=April 2011|reason=link appears to be to dynamic or index page. what is precise attribution?}} {{cite web | author = | url = http://www.hrw.org/en/middle-eastn-africa/bahrain | title = Bahrain | Human Rights Watch | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]] | accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> Amnesty International later released a report saying that Bahraini security forces had used [[live ammunition]] and "extreme force" on protesters without warning and that they had also impeded and assaulted medical staff who were trying to help the wounded. A medic, Hani Mowafi, who was a part of their team in Bahrain said that he "found a pattern of fatal and serious injuries during February's violence showing that the security forces used live ammunition at close range, and apparently targeted protesters' heads, chests and abdomens. They also fired medium-to-large calibre bullets from high-powered rifles on 18 February."<ref>[[Press release]] (17 March 2011). [http://amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/report/evidence-bahraini-security-forces%E2%80%99-brutality-revealed-2011-03-16 "Evidence of Bahraini Security Forces' Brutality Revealed"]. [[Amnesty International]]. Retrieved 21 April 2011.</ref>
[[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] both condemned the use of excessive violence against peaceful demonstrators in Bahrain.<ref>{{dead link|date=April 2011|reason=link appears to be dynamic or index page. what is precise attribution?}} {{cite web | author = | url = http://www.amnesty.org/en/region/bahrain | title = Bahrain | Amnesty International | publisher = [[Amnesty International]] | date=11 February 2011 | accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{dead link|date=April 2011|reason=link appears to be to dynamic or index page. what is precise attribution?}} {{cite web | author = | url = http://www.hrw.org/en/middle-eastn-africa/bahrain | title = Bahrain | Human Rights Watch | publisher = [[Human Rights Watch]] | accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> Amnesty International later released a report saying that Bahraini security forces had used [[live ammunition]] and "extreme force" on protesters without warning and that they had also impeded and assaulted medical staff who were trying to help the wounded. A medic, Hani Mowafi, who was a part of their team in Bahrain said that he "found a pattern of fatal and serious injuries during February's violence showing that the security forces used live ammunition at close range, and apparently targeted protesters' heads, chests and abdomens. They also fired medium-to-large calibre bullets from high-powered rifles on 18 February."<ref>[[Press release]] (17 March 2011). [http://amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/report/evidence-bahraini-security-forces%E2%80%99-brutality-revealed-2011-03-16 "Evidence of Bahraini Security Forces' Brutality Revealed"]. [[Amnesty International]]. Retrieved 21 April 2011.</ref>
Line 445: Line 445:
Organizations in [[Iran]] have announced intentions to launch a [[Bahrain Aid Flotilla]] to draw attention to the "oppression" in Bahrain.<ref name=VOA>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Iranian-Activists-Plan-Aid-Flotilla-to-Bahrain-121575119.html]"Iranian Activists Plan Aid Flotilla to Bahrain", May 10, 2011, Voice of America.</ref><ref name=Fars>[http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9002203922]"Iran to Dispatch Aid Flotilla to Bahrain Next Week", May 10, 2011, Fars News Agency.</ref><ref name=PressTV>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/179157.html]"Iran to send solidarity convoy to Bahrain". May 10, 2011, PressTV.</ref>
Organizations in [[Iran]] have announced intentions to launch a [[Bahrain Aid Flotilla]] to draw attention to the "oppression" in Bahrain.<ref name=VOA>[http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Iranian-Activists-Plan-Aid-Flotilla-to-Bahrain-121575119.html]"Iranian Activists Plan Aid Flotilla to Bahrain", May 10, 2011, Voice of America.</ref><ref name=Fars>[http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.php?nn=9002203922]"Iran to Dispatch Aid Flotilla to Bahrain Next Week", May 10, 2011, Fars News Agency.</ref><ref name=PressTV>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail/179157.html]"Iran to send solidarity convoy to Bahrain". May 10, 2011, PressTV.</ref>

====Commercial news media====
+
===Commercial news media===
[[Qatar]]-based news network [[Al Jazeera]] stated that Bahrain is considered to be the most vulnerable country to unrest amongst Gulf Arab states.<ref name="aljazbahrain" />
[[Qatar]]-based news network [[Al Jazeera]] stated that Bahrain is considered to be the most vulnerable country to unrest amongst Gulf Arab states.<ref name="aljazbahrain" />
In a 14 June 2011 column for ''[[The Independent]]'', veteran [[United Kingdom|British]] Middle East correspondent [[Robert Fisk]] lashed out at Bahraini and Saudi authorities over the treatment of protests and the trial of 48 medical staff on conspiracy charges. He also claimed that the Bahraini government did not invite [[Saudi Arabia]] to send troops into what he suggested should be called "Occupied Bahrain" and said the archipelago is ''de facto'' under Saudi administration, with the government supposedly complying with orders from [[Riyadh]] only to keep up appearances and save face.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-i-saw-these-brave-doctors-trying-to-save-lives-ndash-these-charges-are-a-pack-of-lies-2297100.html|agency=The Independent|first=Robert|last=Fisk|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011|title=Robert Fisk: I saw these brave doctors trying to save lives â these charges are a pack of lies}}</ref>
In a 14 June 2011 column for ''[[The Independent]]'', veteran [[United Kingdom|British]] Middle East correspondent [[Robert Fisk]] lashed out at Bahraini and Saudi authorities over the treatment of protests and the trial of 48 medical staff on conspiracy charges. He also claimed that the Bahraini government did not invite [[Saudi Arabia]] to send troops into what he suggested should be called "Occupied Bahrain" and said the archipelago is ''de facto'' under Saudi administration, with the government supposedly complying with orders from [[Riyadh]] only to keep up appearances and save face.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-i-saw-these-brave-doctors-trying-to-save-lives-ndash-these-charges-are-a-pack-of-lies-2297100.html|agency=The Independent|first=Robert|last=Fisk|date=14 June 2011|accessdate=14 June 2011|title=Robert Fisk: I saw these brave doctors trying to save lives â these charges are a pack of lies}}</ref>
â
====Sports boycotts====
+
===Sports boycotts===
Human rights protesters called for a boycott of the [[Bahrain Grand Prix]] with explicit comparisons to the [[Sporting boycott of South Africa]], and suceeded in having the 2011 race canceled.<ref name=Cary>Tom Cary [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/8553124/Damon-Hill-calls-on-Bernie-Ecclestone-and-Formula-One-to-abandon-Bahrain-Grand-Prix.html]"Damon Hill calls on Bernie Ecclestone and Formula One to abandon Bahrain Grand Prix", June 2, 2011, [[The Daily Telegraph]].</ref><ref>[http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304259304576375282897276062.html?mod=googlenews_wsj}"Bahrain's Crash Course;
Human rights protesters called for a boycott of the [[Bahrain Grand Prix]] with explicit comparisons to the [[Sporting boycott of South Africa]], and suceeded in having the 2011 race canceled.<ref name=Cary>Tom Cary [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/motorsport/formulaone/8553124/Damon-Hill-calls-on-Bernie-Ecclestone-and-Formula-One-to-abandon-Bahrain-Grand-Prix.html]"Damon Hill calls on Bernie Ecclestone and Formula One to abandon Bahrain Grand Prix", June 2, 2011, [[The Daily Telegraph]].</ref><ref>[http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052702304259304576375282897276062.html?mod=googlenews_wsj}"Bahrain's Crash Course;
Formula One drivers for democracy", June 9, 2011, [[Wall Street Journal]].</ref>
Formula One drivers for democracy", June 9, 2011, [[Wall Street Journal]].</ref>
â
====Other====
+
===Other===
Egyptian, but [[Qatar]]-based, Islamic scholar [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] called for the removal of the "roots of oppression" against the Shia majority and for them "to be real citizens of their country". He also criticised the protesters for what he saw as their religious sectarian nature, making reference to reports that the protesters were carrying pictures of the [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Iranian Supreme Leader]] [[Ayatollah]] [[Ali Khamenei]] and [[Hezbollah]]'s [[Sayyid]] [[Hassan Nasrallah]].<ref>{{cite news | author = [[Staff writer]] | date=20 March 2011 | title = Bharaini Sunnis, Shias Should Talk To Resolve Issues: Qaradawi | url = http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/146271-bharaini-sunnis-shias-should-talk-to-resolve-issues-qaradawi.html | work = [[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> He said that the protests were not supported by Sunnis in Bahrain and was thus "invalid". He talked of his friendship with the ruling Al Khalifa family and "praised" King Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa claiming that "the Shiites attacked Sunnis, and took over their mosques, and used weapons just like the hooligans we saw in Yemen and Egypt".<ref>{{cite news | title = Qaradawi Says Bahrain's Revolution Sectarian | author = Alarab, Mohamed | url = http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/03/19/142205.html | work = [[Al Arabiya]] | date=19 March 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref>
Egyptian, but [[Qatar]]-based, Islamic scholar [[Yusuf al-Qaradawi]] called for the removal of the "roots of oppression" against the Shia majority and for them "to be real citizens of their country". He also criticised the protesters for what he saw as their religious sectarian nature, making reference to reports that the protesters were carrying pictures of the [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Iranian Supreme Leader]] [[Ayatollah]] [[Ali Khamenei]] and [[Hezbollah]]'s [[Sayyid]] [[Hassan Nasrallah]].<ref>{{cite news | author = [[Staff writer]] | date=20 March 2011 | title = Bharaini Sunnis, Shias Should Talk To Resolve Issues: Qaradawi | url = http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/146271-bharaini-sunnis-shias-should-talk-to-resolve-issues-qaradawi.html | work = [[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref> He said that the protests were not supported by Sunnis in Bahrain and was thus "invalid". He talked of his friendship with the ruling Al Khalifa family and "praised" King Hamad ibn Isa Al Khalifa claiming that "the Shiites attacked Sunnis, and took over their mosques, and used weapons just like the hooligans we saw in Yemen and Egypt".<ref>{{cite news | title = Qaradawi Says Bahrain's Revolution Sectarian | author = Alarab, Mohamed | url = http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/03/19/142205.html | work = [[Al Arabiya]] | date=19 March 2011 | accessdate=21 April 2011}}</ref>
